A lazy intern encrypted two secret messages with RSA, accidentally reusing a prime. Both ciphertexts are below—can you recover the plaintext? 818164044514827657282568195794484372508518178413572601174956698289801544894600069292770979451041338186874288706993938040495941580409017838376508555539916

The flag format is flag{...}
n=10250267702703277315172397108269530875170383023663784448603518392619003404259452371780167995300254662118215484501836248512107193189288704626512975189298241, e=9321938947479795345109722335162004687259583643248438167983213640758259417200657562040962903398119067555710472870877943091240446789876786621746596172453753

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{q1etfa52}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 818164044514827657282568195794484372508518178413572601174956698289801544894600069292770979451041338186874288706993938040495941580409017838376508555539916
vulnerability: repeated primes
hint: The RSA modulus n is a perfect square. This often indicates a repeated prime usage vulnerability.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=10250267702703277315172397108269530875170383023663784448603518392619003404259452371780167995300254662118215484501836248512107193189288704626512975189298241, e=9321938947479795345109722335162004687259583643248438167983213640758259417200657562040962903398119067555710472870877943091240446789876786621746596172453753
extra_info: p=101243605737366334256189742620576342379656165465635227788497168395415216055329, q=101243605737366334256189742620576342379656165465635227788497168395415216055329, φ(n)=10250267702703277315172397108269530875170383023663784448603518392619003404259249884568693262631742282632974331817076936181175922733711710289722144757187584
subtype: repeated_prime_usage
